Key Arguments: The Bill infringes on free speech rights.
The Bill itself is a threat to democracy, potentially leading towards a totalitarian state.
The exclusion of government-authorized content from the Bill is hypocritical, as governments are often sources of misinformation.
The financial penalties proposed in the Bill are excessively harsh and could be used to financially destroy individuals.
Main Themes: Historical and international context of human rights
Notable Quotes: The fact is that this very Bill is the threat to our Democracy.
In 1948 Australia helped draft Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights which says 'Everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression...'
The penalties are just outrageous and it appears are meant to provide the ability to remove people from the scene by destroying them financially.
